{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Cyndi Thomson | image = | caption = | image_size = | birth_name = | alias = Cyndi Goodman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|10|19}} | death_date = | origin = [[Tifton, Georgia|Tifton]], Georgia, United States{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p478481/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Cyndi Thomson biography |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |last=Loftus |first=Johnny |work=[[Allmusic]]}} | instrument = Vocals | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2000–2002, 2006–present | label = [[Capitol Records|Capitol Nashville]] | associated_acts = [[Gary Allan]] | website = }} '''Cyndi Thomson''' (born October 19, 1976) is an American [[country music]] artist. Thomson wrote songs with songwriter [[Tommy Lee James]] and in 2000, she signed with [[Capitol Records Nashville]] as a recording artist. She released her first album, ''[[My World (Cyndi Thomson album)|My World]]'', in 2001 and her debut single, "[[What I Really Meant to Say]]", became a number one hit on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. She later abandoned her recording career in 2002, but resumed recording in 2006. ==Biography== ===Early life=== Cyndi Thomson was born and raised in [[Tifton, Georgia|Tifton]], Georgia, the youngest of four daughters of Pat and Russ Thomson. As a child, she was exposed to many different types of music. Her parents listened to the [[oldies]] while her sisters listened to music by [[The Manhattan Transfer|Manhattan Transfer]] and [[Janet Jackson]] among others.{{cite web | author = Perlman, Jason | date = July 24, 2001 | url = http://www.musicohio.com/interviews/archive/cyndithomson.html | title = Cyndi Thomson | publisher = MusicOhio | accessdate = July 18, 2007 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172414/http://www.musicohio.com/interviews/archive/cyndithomson.html | archive-date = March 3, 2016 | url-status = dead }} As Thomson got older, she began singing in church like her sisters did. At the age of twelve, she knew that she wanted to be a singer and at thirteen, after listening to [[Trisha Yearwood]]'s "[[She's in Love with the Boy]]", she knew that she wanted to be a country singer.{{cite web | author = Gray, Michael | date = August 2, 2001 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1445919/20010801/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930045803/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1445919/20010801/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = September 30, 2007 | title = Cyndi Thomson's "World" Shaped by Trisha Yearwood | publisher = [[Country Music Television]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} After graduating high school and winning a Georgia Music Hall of Fame scholarship,{{cite web | date = April 7, 2000 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476883/20030813/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044429/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1476883/20030813/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = September 30, 2007 | title = Thomson Joins Capitol Nashville Roster | publisher = [[Country Music Television]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} Thomson attended [[Kennesaw State University]] in [[Kennesaw, Georgia|Kennesaw]].{{cite web | author = Blankenship, Bill | date = October 26, 2001 | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4179/is_20011026/ai_n11771994 | title = Sweet young twang | publisher = [[The Topeka Capital-Journal]] | accessdate = July 26, 2007 }} Feeling that her dream of being a country singer was not going to be realized staying in Atlanta, she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], Tennessee. There, she attended [[Belmont University]] and enrolled in its music business program, but dropped out after a year and a half realizing that school was not necessary for her to do what she wanted to do. Thomson did various jobs while pursuing the recording career that she wanted, one of which was a modelling job at a party for [[Deana Carter]]'s album ''[[Did I Shave My Legs for This?]]'' going platinum. One of the other models there later introduced Thomson to songwriter [[Tommy Lee James]],{{cite web | author = Mansfield, Brian | date = August 9, 2001 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/2001-08-09-cyndi-thomson.htm | title = Everything is just peachy for Thomson | publisher = [[USA Today]] | accessdate = July 25, 2007 }} who wrote for [[Brooks & Dunn]] and [[Martina McBride]]. ===Music career=== Even though Thomson had never written a song before, James agreed to work with her and within a year of writing their first song, Thomson signed with [[Sony-ATV Music Publishing]] as a songwriter. In 2000, James introduced Thomson to [[Capitol Records Nashville]] which signed her to a record deal immediately after hearing her sing three songs. Thomson co-wrote eight of the eleven songs on her debut album ''My World'', released on July 31, 2001. Co-produced by James and producer [[Paul Worley]], it became the best-selling debut album by a female country singer since [[LeAnn Rimes]]' album ''[[Blue (LeAnn Rimes album)|Blue]]'' was released in 1996.{{cite web | author = Nash, Alanna | date = October 19, 2001 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,253970,00.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071016144402/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,253970,00.html | url-status = dead | archive-date = October 16, 2007 | title = Georgia Peach | publisher = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} The album was certified gold, for selling more than 500,000 copies, by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] ten months after the album's release.{{cite web | date = June 2, 2002 | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2002_June_6/ai_86855490/pg_1 | title = Cyndi Thomson Goes GOLD! Capitol Recording Artist's Debut Album Sells Over 500,000 Units | publisher = [[Business Wire]] | accessdate = July 17, 2007 }}{{cite web | date = June 7, 2002 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1455078/20020607/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930040857/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1455078/20020607/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = September 30, 2007 | title = Thomson Hits Gold Standard | publisher = [[Country Music Television]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} Lead-off single "[[What I Really Meant to Say]]," written after an encounter with an older boy at a party one night, spent three weeks at the top of the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts. It also became the only debut single by a female country singer to spend more than one week at the top of the [[Radio & Records]] country chart. Her next two singles, "I Always Liked That Best" and "I'm Gone", failed to reach the top 20, with the former peaking at No. 21 and the latter peaking at No. 31 on the ''Billboard'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart. In late 2002, Thomson, in a letter written to her record label, fans and friends, announced that she was walking away from her recording career.{{cite web | date = October 15, 2002 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1458104/20021012/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930030847/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1458104/20021012/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = September 30, 2007 | title = Thomson to Give Up Recording Career | publisher = [[Country Music Television]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} Thomson, who married musician and producer Daniel Goodman earlier that year, stated that being a recording artist was an "overwhelming life changing experience" and that she "cannot commit to [the] obligations" of making a new album. She did, however, contribute to the 2004 album ''Amazing Grace 3: A Country Salute to Gospel'', on which she sang "'Tis So Sweet to Trust in Jesus".{{cite web | author = Wadley, Carma | date = August 7, 2004 | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20040807/ai_n11467751 | title = Singer's life takes a sharp turn | publisher = Deseret News Publishing Co. | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} She also sang "Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas" for the album ''Christmas Angels'' released by Capitol Nashville in 2005.{{cite web | date = November 8, 2005 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1513280/20051108/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930011141/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1513280/20051108/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = September 30, 2007 | title = Country Christmas Albums Released | publisher = [[Country Music Television]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }}{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B000BM6AO2/musiccityusa-20 | title = Christmas Angels | publisher = [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} "[[Life Ain't Always Beautiful]]", co-written by Thomson and credited to her as Cyndi Goodman, became a top five hit for [[Gary Allan]] in 2006. That year, she also returned to Capitol Nashville after leaving the label for four years and started recording for her second album with James.{{cite web | date = January 12, 2006 | url = http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1520615/20060112/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044356/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1520615/20060112/thomson_cyndi.jhtml | url-status = dead | archive-date = September 30, 2007 | title = Cyndi Thomson Returns to Capitol Nashville | publisher = [[Country Music Television]] | accessdate = July 18, 2007 }} On October 29, 2009, Thomson released her first new music album in eight years, ''This Time'', a digital-only EP featuring five original songs. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
